> >  >>
> >  >>>>The typical result is that latest jdk (1.4) are 30%-100% 
slower than
> >  >>>>c/c++ code.
> >  >>>
> >  >>>100% slower?  You mean, I assume, that when you run C++ the
> >  >>>Java is too embarassed to run at all?
> >  >>
> >  >> Huh?
> >  >>
> >  >> If the C++ program takes 10 seconds, how much is 100% of 
that? What
> >  >> would it give you if the Java version where slower by that 
amount?
> > 
> >  > I didn't expected this to be so strange. If c++ prog takes 100 
seconds,
> >  > 10% more is 110, 30% more is 130 and 100% more is simply 200.
> > 
> > Yes. I think one might usually say "twice as slow", or better 
yet, "took
> > twice as long".
> > 
> > Tonight it is going down to zero. Tomorrow it is going to be 
twice as cold.

To be technical here, Temperature is not a ratio variable, it is an 
interval variable.  There is no 'zero' in temperature so it is not 
correct to say it is going to be twice as cold tomorrow. And yes, I 
know there is 'absolute' zero but ask any statistician and he will 
tell you that using ratios with our normal temperature scales is 
simply wrong.  Using ratios with time works if you are using timed 
tests and define 'zero' as no time.  Then yes, 5 minutes is twice as 
slow as 10 minutes.  Before benchmarking make sure you have a ratio 
level variable if you want to express your results in ratios.  Then 
you must define the zero point otherwise your ratios are 
meaningless.  


Matt --
